section.hand:
To M
r
Secret. Au
g
26. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 26 Au
g
To M
r
Secretary from M Bodley
Yt may please yo
r
H. since
e death of
Schenck
wee have had much a doo
& [care] litle to have more w
th
his garrison of [
S'gravenweert
] in
Guelders
the souldiers ther demand theyr full payment for all
e time
t
is past
& require to Rx yt w
th
in 5 wekes, wh
r
uppon
e
Counsell
hath sent to Schenck
wyddow to come heth
r
w
th
some oth
r
of
e principall of
e garrison, whe[re]
they
mise to satisfy as theyr ability will
mitt, but how
ey wilbe
swaded to come we do not yet und
r
stand. Astouching the
French
Embas
s
request they have agreed to lend
e
K.
yf so be he shall need
30000 crownes to be payd in p
nt
mony w
th
in 2 monethes after they
shall have Rxd
e K obliga
o
n. The
States of Utrecht
have
onely dissented, wherby theyr grant would be frustrat but
t
at
e instance of
e Deputies of oth
r
provinces the counsell of State
is contented to become bound that those of Utrecht shall contribute
& to
t
effect
e counsell hath alredy written theyr letters to induce
the States of
t
province. The Embas
s
hath not had this
answer formally delivered but I suppose yt wilbe don to day
& as far as I
ceave he wilbe urgent uppon them, to have
the time of
e 2 monethes cutt of. They ar very officious
unto him & travell much to dispatch him to his best contentation.
They do also deliberate & as yt should seeme they will resolve
uppon yt out of hand, to send some embassador to
e F
r
King
to congratulat his happines. The
D. of Parma
continueth
still at
e Spa where we learne by letters lately int
r
cepted
t
he hath divers practizes in hand w
ch
put him in some hope
of
e conquest of
Holland:
yt is also thought
t
he dealeth
w
th
e Bishope of
Liege
to use
Mons
r
De Merode
S
r
Thomas
Morgans
father in Lawe (who hath great possesions in
e Land
of Liege, & doth enjoy the dignitye there Du grand revenew)
for an instrument to work
e meanes w
th
S
r
Thomas to succour
e Towne. But
t
he hath bin dealt w
th
all as yet by his
father we cannot
ceave, nev
r
theles yt should seeme very
necessary that
e principall Captaines of
e garrison being
all absent & scarce any at all p
nt
theryn might be order
aken for theyr retourne. For theyr presence & Counsell will
make very much for
e safegard of
e place. Uppon l
re
s
that were written of Late by
Vierslet
(one
t
heertofore
was lieutenant to my
L. Willughbies
cornet) but revolted to
e
Ennemy since my L. de
ture into
England.)
to some of his old
friends, souldiers in
e garrison of
Berghen,
w
ch
were by them
im
ted to
e Gouverno
r
, there hath bin a plott laid w
th
the
[privity] & advise of
e Governo
r
how
e said souldiers most
induce Vierslet to attempt the surprise of
e Towne by
night, whertoo he hath bin trayned on so farr, as
e time
approcheth of effecting his purpose, w
ch
he doth promise to
execute w
th
3 or 4000 men, S
r
Thomas is in good hope
upon such
vision as he hath made to give
e Ennemy a
notable overthrowe, the practise hath bin im
ted heer to
e
Counsell, & to
Count Maurice
at
e Camp The Count ys very
desyrous to have yt put in execution / but
e counsell have
fol.114v
no liking unto yt & so they have willed
M
r
Gilpin
to report to
e
Gouverno
r
, For they held such exploit
to bee free of daunger, they
find
e Comp
s
there very weake & they stand in feare of [wrong]
measure for
t
e Ennemy they thinke will [never] deale uppon unc
r
tainty
having bin so notoriously trapped so lately before / Nev
r
theles because
they finde
e Count so forward & for
t
the gouverno
r
& other
Captaynes of experience make no difficulty in yt, they have written
that
e Gouverno
r
may use his discretion, So
t
the Towne by
this meanes bee not put in hazard. But of all this matter M
r
Gilpin will enforme yo
r
H. from Berchen.
